message.content: This question requires some knowledge about animal behavior and inheritance. A Bald Eagle's ability to build its nest is a biological trait that is passed down in its genes. Option (A) is incorrect because observation of others is not the primary way in which Bald Eagles learn to build their nest. Option (C) is incorrect because trial and error is not the main method of learning for Bald Eagles when it comes to nest-building. Option (D) is incorrect because while Bald Eagles may observe their parents in the nest-building process, their ability to build nests is primarily instinctual rather than learned.

Option (A) is incorrect because observation of others is not the primary way that animals learn to build nests. Option (C) is partially true as trial and error may play a role in refining nest-building skills, but the initial ability is inherited. Option (D) is incorrect because bald eagles do not rely primarily on parental teaching to learn how to build nests.

Option (D) is incorrect because Bald Eagles do not learn from their parents how to build a nest, as they are solitary animals and do not have a strong parental bond like some other species.
